etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Robert Mannyng (d. c1338), poet and historian. Partly from account + -er, and partly from Anglo-Norman acontur, acuntur, acountour accountant, auditor from aconter, acunter, acounter + -ur, -our

definitions: A person who accounts, reckons, or calculates. Also: one who presents an account (of money, responsibilities, etc.). Compare "accountant", "counter".
